instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2289: What is A2289? A2289 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2020 with EMC 3456, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01987..
definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.P5VG3S_PGOOD: What is P5VG3S_PGOOD? P5VG3S_PGOOD is a signal that indicates that the PP5V_G3S power rail is functioning properly. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Hello community !
I have a MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar that initially had a screen replacement issue. Being the king of small tests, I wanted to test to see if an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> screen could potentially work on this model. #BadIdea

Currently, the motherboard (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) partially supports the 20V load. That is to say that the USBC-A takes 20V directly without going through 5V. And the USBC-B goes through 5V then 20V. The 2 charge ports are in 0.5A unstable, and are close to 10W but always drop down to approximately 1W unstable.

This Macbook doesn't turn on any more (on the other hand the trackpad which reacts randomly to the click). Have you ever encountered this type of failure on this model ?

So, while testing the voltages, I unsealed a few issues with the circuits, and I'm wondering if you could help me find where the problem is coming from ?

- <SIGNAL>P5VG3S_PGOOD</SIGNAL> - 1.76v instead of 5v
It is important to specify that the voltage is not stable. This decreases slightly every second to drop to 0v after about 3 seconds. Then back to 1.76v, etc ...

- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0 instead of 3v3
- <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL> - 0 instead of 1V8
- <SIGNAL>PPVPCORE_S5</SIGNAL> - 0 instead of 0.7-1V
- <SIGNAL>PP1V_PRIM</SIGNAL> (PCH POWER) - 0 instead of 1V

- <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> - 0 instead of 1V8
- <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> - 0 instead of 1V2
- <SIGNAL>PP1V_S3</SIGNAL> - 0 instead of 1V
- <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL> - 0 instead of 1V2
- <SIGNAL>PP1V_S0SW</SIGNAL> - 0 instead of 1V
- PPVCCIO (CPU GFX) - 0 instead of 0.95V
- <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0 instead of 0.55 - 1.5V
- <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0 instead of 0.55 - 1.15V
- <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0 instead of 0.55 - 1.5V

All other voltage are normal.

Do you have a solution?
thank you in advance for your help

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Be aware of wrong assumptios!!!
"<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_PGOOD</SIGNAL> - 1.76v instead of 5v"
Don't make confusion between signal name and its nominal voltage.
The above mentioned signal is not a power rail; is just used to indicate a proper working state of <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power supply.
It has correct voltage, being pulled-up to <SIGNAL>1V8_G3S</SIGNAL>.

<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> LCD assembly can be used for test.
However, no reason for video test yet, as you don't get CPU core voltage.
"<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0"
Many other voltages must come on before CPU gets core voltage.

"initially had a screen replacement issue"
What's the full history?

The MLB can be tested alone on the desk, without LCD connected; nor even external monitor is needed.
Connect charger (no battery) and check for voltage on the big coils.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Thank you for your response and for taking the time to help me.

This macbook arrived with a broken screen. Initially, the Macbook allowed us to have a signal on an external monitor, so it would turn on.

I wanted to test an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> screen out of curiosity and then replaced the screen with a functional screen with a good reference (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>). Finally, I noticed the problem described above.

Which lines do you think should be tested ?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 84037, member: 682"]
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Be aware of wrong assumptios!!!
"<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_PGOOD</SIGNAL> - 1.76v instead of 5v"
Don't make confusion between signal name and its nominal voltage.
The above mentioned signal is not a power rail; is just used to indicate a proper working state of <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power supply.
It has correct voltage, being pulled-up to <SIGNAL>1V8_G3S</SIGNAL>.

<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> LCD assembly can be used for test.
However, no reason for video test yet, as you don't get CPU core voltage.
"<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0"
Many other voltages must come on before CPU gets core voltage.

"initially had a screen replacement issue"
What's the full history?

The MLB can be tested alone on the desk, without LCD connected; nor even external monitor is needed.
Connect charger (no battery) and check for voltage on the big coils.
[/QUOTE]


Thank you for your response and for taking the time to help me.

This macbook arrived with a broken screen. Initially, the Macbook allowed us to have a signal on an external monitor, so it would turn on.

I wanted to test an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> screen out of curiosity and then replaced the screen with a functional screen with a good reference (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>). Finally, I noticed the problem described above.

As you asked me, here are the voltage's coils : 

L8100 0.00v
L8102 0.00v
L7210 0.00v
L7220 0.00v
L7702 0.00v
L7420 0.00v
L7410 0.00v
L8410 0.00v

L7030 (<SIGNAL>CHGER_LX1</SIGNAL>/LX2) voltage variable 0.03 - 3.9/4.00 - 12.1v
L7670 (P5VG3S) voltage variable 1.9 - 3.3v
L7690 (PP3V3G3H) voltage variable 0.01 - 3.3v

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Did you disconnect the battery, before touching LCD connector?

As always for T2 machines, try DFU mode.
More information available here:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]
Follow exactly the tutorial steps.

Write directly into reply box, instead of clicking Reply button.
No reason to quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
Please, maintain the forum aesthetic...

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Yes, we disconnected the battery before touching the LCD connector.
I tried DFU mode (Normal and Deep Dive), but no results. Still no screen, no power, no fan :cry:

What do you think of the above results for the coils ?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Don't touch L7030; it is not connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Check if get steady voltage at F7000 and <RESISTOR>R6934</RESISTOR>.

Did you complete DFU revive, or machine is not recognized in DFU?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Battery disconnected, and USB-C cable connected :

F7000 (1 and 2) give 12.3v
<RESISTOR>R6934</RESISTOR> (1 and 2) give 3.3v

About DFU, the macbook is not recognized. No "DFU image" appear on the app "Apple Configurator 2", No apple logo on the defective macbook, nothing :/

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message: Check if all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages come on.

threads.message:
Here are the voltages :

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : loop from 0v to 1v8 
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : loop from 0v to 0v7
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE : loop from 0v to 0v8
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : loop from 0v to 3v3
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : loop from 0v to 1v2

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> : loop from 0v to 1v1

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
That explains no DFU connection.

Do you have stable voltage at F7000 and <RESISTOR>R6934</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message: Yes, both are stable. No loop, no variation

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Check for short on all other coils of <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>; not AWAKE, nor SLPS2R related.
Also check on all big coils and other secondary supplies; look in pages 69 & 73/4/5.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
About <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, it seems all coils are ok. About voltage, 
- L7815/L7814 : loop from 0v to 1v1
- L7816/L7815 : loop from 0v to 0v9
- L7813 : loop from 0v to 1v8
- L7823 (no stuff) : loop from 0v to 0v1
- L7806/L7807/L7808/L7809 : loop from 0v to 0v75
- L7811/L7812 : loop from 0v to 0v82
- L7810 : loop from 0v to 0v8
- L7824 (no stuff) : 0v8 stable
- L7821/L7822/L7820/L7819 : 0v


<CHIP>U7710</CHIP> : All pins are 0v
<CHIP>U8100</CHIP> : All pins are 0v

<CHIP>U8200</CHIP> : pin 1/3 : 3v2 stable. All other pins are 0v
<CHIP>U8220</CHIP> : pin 1 : 3v3 stable. pin 3 : 1v7 satble. All other pins are 0v
<CHIP>U8207</CHIP> : All pins are 0v
<CHIP>U8208</CHIP> : All pins are 0v
<CHIP>U8250</CHIP> : pin 2 : 3v2 stable. All other pins are 0v
<TRANSISTOR>Q8251</TRANSISTOR> : pin 5/6 : 3v2 stable. All other pins are 0v
<CHIP>U8213</CHIP> : pin 1/3 : 0v5 stable. All other pins are 0v
<CHIP>U8290</CHIP> : pin 3 : 3v3 stable. All other pins are 0v

<CHIP>U8400</CHIP> :
- pin 21 : 10v7 stable
- pin 13 and 14 0v9 stable
- pin 11 : 12v16 stable
- pin 9/10 : 12v3 stable
- pin 1/2 : 0v09
- All other pins are 0v

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Posting 0V on some power rails doesn't help to much.
In such case, you sould check diode mode to ground; switch to ohm scale, for very low values.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
No need to check all chips pins.
I expected the values on the output pins.
BTW, my error about page 75; no need to check it, yet.

However, from your readings, seems to have very low resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL>.
Post the exact ohm value to ground at L7670.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
As I begin, I didn't know what to give you exactly :p
In this case, it is better to be too complete than not enough haha

About the L7670, the exact ohm value is  0012 ohm.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
That is really low value for <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power rail.
You can try voltage injection method.
Start with 3V and slowly go to 5.5V (if needed).
May need time injecting around 5V and thermal camera can help you.
Not sure if you can detect something heated just with fingers; as the ressistance is not very low.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
It seems that the components <RESISTOR>R8444</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R8445</RESISTOR> are faulty because the temperature is very high and their diode value is OL.
I'll replace them and check what's going on :)

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
A resistor cannot generate short to ground, or low resistance value!!!

What is the exact resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <CAPACITOR>C8440</CAPACITOR>/41?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 435 ohm

<CAPACITOR>C8440</CAPACITOR> : 
- pin 1 : 0001 ohm
- pin 2 : 0000 ohm

<CAPACITOR>C8441</CAPACITOR> : 
- pin 1 : 0013 ohm
- pin 2 : 0000 ohm

It looks like the <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> heats up a lot too.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Very likely bad <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>.
To be sure, remove <CAPACITOR>C8440</CAPACITOR> and check again.

BTW, save your time and do not measure again ground to ground points...

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
When I remove <CAPACITOR>C8440</CAPACITOR>, <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> heats up a lot.

BTW, I wish you a happy new year 2022 :)

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
I didn't expect you to power up the board again.
Did you check diode mode to ground, once <CAPACITOR>C8440</CAPACITOR> removed?

Happy new year too for you and all forum members!

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Yes, that's the same diode value

<CAPACITOR>C8440</CAPACITOR> : 0001 ohm
<CAPACITOR>C8441</CAPACITOR> : 0013 ohm

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Then change <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>.

BTW, check diode mode again, once chip is removed.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
I removed <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> and the diode value are :
<CAPACITOR>C8440</CAPACITOR> : 0410 ohm
<CAPACITOR>C8441</CAPACITOR> : 0399 ohm

Could you please confirm to me that <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> is the same as the <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> you are selling here ? [URL]https://store.rossmanngroup.com/b4-lp8548b1sq.html[/URL]

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Contact store staff for any doubt.
Chips should be the same, if is LP8548B1SQ and has the same package.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Hello,
I removed <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> and I replaced it. Unfortunately the MacBook doesn't turn on.

BTW,the diode value are stable :
<CAPACITOR>C8440</CAPACITOR> : 0410 ohm
<CAPACITOR>C8441</CAPACITOR> : 0399 ohm

What do you advise me ? 
How are you able to check the diode value ? I mean, which tool do you use ?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
MacBook should turn on even without <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>.
If not, you have more problems on the MLB.
Possibly overvoltage on 5V power rail damaged more things...

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Thanks for your feedback. 
In this case, what would you do ?

What software do you recommend I use to check the diode values? I use XZZ or Refox, but it's incomplete...

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message: I don't understand the question about software...

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
I would really like to repair this macbook but I think I don't have the right software or the right knowledge to do it.
So I joined this forum to learn as much as possible.

That's why I would like to know what software you used to guide me as our comments ? Because the software I use (XZZ and Refox) doesn't show me the diode values for MacBook. So I can't check if the values I have are accurate. Yet you were able to tell me if they were abnormal. I would have liked to know how you managed to find the right Diode Value ? :)

Also, you said me " Possibly overvoltage on 5V power rail damaged more things... ". Could you tell me what you would do first to check where the problem is ? Concretely, I would like to understand the systematics (the first things to do) in this type of case.

Awaiting your reply,
Many thanks

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
There is no software to show you the correct diode mode readings; apart of readings took from good working board.

You've said to get external video initially.
What happened from that moment until board died?
Wrong manipulation in the process, knocked off components; something must explain the overvoltage on the <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power rail.

Does the board stay on if starts in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Ok, and which software do you recommend for bitmaps and schematics ? Currently I use XinZhiZao and Refox software, do you use another one ?

Honestly, I can't tell you more... I'm sorry.
What I do know is that this device was dropped off to us for a screen replacement. We tested sending the image to an external monitor, and it worked.
Then, I tested a macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> screen for my personal cultivation, and I didn't have any image on the screen.
After checking the motherboard, I know that it accepts 20V.
Then I check with the thermal camera, the T2 chip heats up very slightly (30Â°C/86Â°F), but no other component heats up.

Where do you recommend me to start on <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> ?

Could you tell me more about the Bypass SMC ?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Read here about SMC bypass and more information.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

I use Openboardview 8.0 to see boardview files and Acrobat Reader for schematics.

I can't really understand how the <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> got damaged in the process of screen replacement, other than bad manipulation; maybe battery wasn't disconnected.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message: In this case, for a macbook that no longer turns on, and for which we do not know the exact cause of the short circuit. What do you recommend that I do ? Where do I start to diagnose it ?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> TouchBar (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) - No power / No image
threads.message:
Once no very low resistance remains to ground after <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> was removed, not easy to find another damaged chip.
I don't exactly know diode mode reading for a good working board at <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL>, for comparison.
Changing chips one by one is a nightmare; maybe not worth to continue.
